Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Developing a Framework for Mitigating Environmental Externalities in the Power Sector to Maximize Regional Outcomes

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1632945
Sanders, Kelly

This project proposes to develop the foundation for a potentially transformative and interdisciplinary approach to reduce the environmental and social impacts of the electric power sector through a dynamic market-based solution. There are two major research objectives: (1) understanding the fundamental drivers of variations in local power plant efficiency, and (2) developing a new approach to formulating a mathematical framework for power plant dispatching based on the spatio-temporal prioritization of local air quality conditions, water constraints, and anticipated levels of climate stress. Although modifying the "business as usual" dispatching protocol would likely result in higher direct costs to consumers, this project will analyze the benefits that could result in achieving air, water, and climate improvements and how this strategy compares in cost to other mitigation strategies. The proposed strategy is targeted to determine the best power plant fleet to meet demand reliably, while minimizing environmental and social consequences.

The societal impact of this research is potentially far-reaching, offering an innovative mathematical framework that may reduce the social and environmental costs of power generation without new power infrastructure investments. While many sustainability investments may disproportionally benefit populations that are able to pay a premium, the proposed framework offers a systems-scale intervention that strategically identifies regions that would benefit the most from reductions in local power generation. The geostatistical framework proposed can also be used more generally to inform the placement of new infrastructure investments and regions that could be targeted for new sustainability interventions based on greatest potential benefits.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The US power sector represents approximately 41% of water withdrawals, 4% of water consumption, 36% of carbon dioxide equivalent greenhouse gas emissions (GHGs), 73% of sulfur oxide emissions, and a significant proportion of nitrous oxide emissions, nationally. The consequences of these environmental impacts vary substantially across time and space, as well as across power generation technologies and fuels. Despite the importance of mitigating the environmental externalties of the power sector, there exist critical knowledge gaps regarding how to quantify and compare these environmental impacts on relevant spatio-temporal scales, particularly in a future of anticipated warming, which is expected to reduce the efficiency of existing power generation infrastructure. Filling these knowledge gaps is critical to developing frameworks to provide accountability in terms of reporting and mitigating the lifecycle water and emissions consequences of the power sector.

The goals of this project were to 1) understand the climate-driven impacts on power plant efficiency and energy consumption, 2) develop high resolution datasets to understand the regional water use impacts of energy production and consumption that can be compared to readily available datasets of power plant-related greenhouse gases and air quality pollutants, and 3) evaluate new frameworks to build accountability regarding the environmental impacts of energy consumption and reduce the social and environmental costs of power generation in the United States.

Intellectual Merit: A great deal of work has been dedicated to improving air quality impacts, water use consequences, and climate change mitigation strategies in the power sector. However, studies to address these priorities are often siloed and can result in a solution for one environmental criterion that imposes a negative impact on another environmental criterion, pointing to the need of more holistic solutions. This project developed novel datasets and frameworks to quantify the regional impacts of power generation across multiple criteria to facillitate more holistic evaluation. National estimates of the absolute water use and water use intensities of primary energy conversion, transportation, processing, electricity generation, and waste management were developed and integrated into a novel framework to account for the lifecycle consequences of electricity consumption. The results are being used to develop emissions and water use mitigation strategies within the power sector. 

Broader impacts: The geostatistical framework developed through this effort can be used to inform power plant dispatching strategies, the placement of new infrastructure investments, and regions that should be targeted for new sustainability interventions. As disadvantaged communities tend to live in the regions with the highest levels of pollution, the data generated through this effort can provide the foundation for solutions to greatly increase environmental justice in underserved communities. The knowledge created through this project was incorporated into six 4-hour climate change workshops delivered to K-12 students and teachers from underserved communities in South Central Los Angeles. This research was also incorporated into existing course work at the University of Southern California and will support the PhD research activities of underrepresented minorities in engineering.
